section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need a variety of classroom items in quantities from one to ten, such as blocks, books, and more.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Hooray for Hoppy, we talked about how Hoppy used his senses to tell it was spring. We also counted how many lambs, flowers, and other things we saw.

In this activity, I will count how many of an item there are. I will point to each one and say the number as I count it. I might make a mistake though! Every time I make a mistake, I want you to help me out by raising your hand and telling me what my mistake was. Then we can fix it together.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place five books on the table. Begin counting them out loud one at a time, pointing to each as you say a number. Pause and look for children to raise their hands after each count. When you get to the fourth one, say nothing, then point to the fifth and say the number four instead.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Did I make a mistake? What was it? How can I fix it?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity, making new mistakes, including pointing to one you already counted, skipping numbers, swapping letters with numbers, and counting out of order.
Extend Have children demonstrate the correct way to count for you.

Talk About Counting Discuss with children what mistakes you made. Have them share what the mistake was and how they identified it. Ask children how they fixed the counting mistakes you made. Point out that the counting sequence is always the same.

Some children may become unhappy or angry when someone makes a mistake. Help them identify the frustration and reframe the mistake as an opportunity to learn something new. Remind children that everyone makes mistakes, including teachers and other adults.
Count different types of items together, such as crayons and markers. Ask children why this does not change the method for counting.
Before the activity, review the number words with children from one to ten. After children raise their hands, give them time to figure out how to describe your mistake, and provide prompts as needed.
Encourage children to use their fingers to point to each item as they help you count and fix your mistakes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you’ll need ten Connecting Cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Hooray for Hoppy, we talked about how Hoppy felt about spring and counted the numbers of different things he saw.

In this activity, I will hold Connecting Cubes behind my back. You’ll guess how many I am hiding. Then we will count the cubes together and say whose guess is closest! After we count, we will talk about how we feel.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Put one to ten Connecting Cubes in your hands or behind your back, so that children cannot see how many you have.
Ask How many cubes do you think I have? Give each child in the small group a chance to guess. Once all children have guessed, place the cubes on the table and count the cubes together.

Extend Think aloud as you count with children. Point out how you say one count per cube. Show how you can move each cube after you count it to keep track of which cubes you have counted. Show children how the number counted is always the same regardless of what order the cubes are counted in.
Repeat Continue the activity, hiding different numbers of cubes each time.

Talk About Feelings Discuss with children how they chose what number to guess. Talk about how you counted, and how they felt afterward. Ask how they felt, and how it was to share those emotions with the group.
To create a simpler version of the activity, use five or fewer cubes. Help children count by reminding them any type of item can be counted, and review strategies before and during counting.
Have children hold cubes behind their backs instead. Guide children to take turns counting the cubes after they are revealed.
Review the numbers one to ten, showing the numeral on a Number Card or Magnetic Number. Also make sure children understand that a guess is distinct from knowing the actual quantity.

Children who have trouble sharing in the large group may feel more comfortable opening up in this setting. Provide these children with space to formulate their words and time to speak to encourage them in particular.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Hooray for Hoppy! we talked about how Hoppy called the other rabbits. We also talked about what order Hoppy did things in. Just like actions, objects can be in order.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the words second and last. Use the second and last Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will pretend to be rabbits having a parade. We will line up, and announce what order we are standing in by saying we are first, second, third, fourth, or last.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Have children line up neatly in any order.
Have each child announce their position using ordinal terms. Then go on a short “parade” in a circle around the table. You can provide ribbons or batons to use for the parade if you wish.
Repeat Have children line up in a new order, announce their positions, and parade again several times. Point out to children that this is the second, third, etc, parade you are doing.

Talk About Ordinal Numbers Discuss the ordinal terms with children. Point out how they connect to cardinal numbers. Together with children, come up with situations where using the ordinal terms could be helpful and useful, and instances where they may already use them.

Provide prompts to children to help them state their positions in line. Children may have trouble with the endings of the words and say foured, or threeth, based on other ordinal numbers. Point out how they are close and provide the correct word.
Add complexity by having children arrange themselves by a characteristic such as height, shirt colors, birthdays, or some other simple quality.

Review the ordinal terms for the number of children in your group, using a collection of objects and pointing, and have them repeat after you. Children may be unfamiliar with the term parade, but you can describe it as a walk instead.

Encourage children to hop gently as they announce their positions and move around in the parade to develop their gross motor skills. Make sure they are aware their surroundings and are careful not to disturb others.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read See, Smell, Hear, Taste, and Touch! we talked about the five senses and the number five.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Practice identifying numerals with children. Lay the Number Cards on the table in order from one to nine. Point to each card one at a time, say the name of the number, and display that number of Connecting Cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will call out a number. When it is your turn, you will pick up a card with that number on it and show it to me. The goal is to make a match between what I say and what you pick up.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Lay out the Number Cards on the table in order. Call on children one at a time.
Wait for the child to pick up the correct card. If it’s a match, announce the match. If not, provide the child with prompts to help.
Repeat Continue until each child has matched a numeral twice.
Extend Switch roles slightly. Hold up a Number Card, and have the child announce what number is shown.
Talk About Numerals Point out places children might see numerals. Discuss how they can recognize them, and how knowing them can help with phones, addresses, page numbers, and more.
Start with the numerals one to five to create a simpler version of the game. As children become more proficient with identifying numerals, you can add in the remaining numerals in later rounds.
Ask children to write each numeral on a piece of paper or mini-white board as you call it out. Have children hold up the paper or white board and help correct any errors.

If children are having trouble with the names of the numbers during the extend portion, encourage them to say the name of the number in their home language. You can then repeat the number in English, and have them repeat it after you.

Use the Magnetic Numerals rather than the Number Cards, and encourage children to hold them in their hands and trace the shapes of them with their fingers to become more familiar with the forms of the numerals. Point out to children that this uses their sense of touch in addition to their sense of sound.
